elements.content: Complex surface dynamics is the key to limit the photoelectrochemical performance of hematite, while its core content is the hole trapping and release by surface traps. Deep traps are accompanied by extremely fast capture rates and extremely slow release rates, which severely suppress the hole transport process. Herein, we proposed a unique method to progressively convert deep traps on the hematite surface for fast hole transfer via in situ one-step metal organic framework modification. This stepwise deep-trap passivation is achieved by hematite corrosion first on the surface and subsequent construction of a porous titanium layer. The gentle trap finishing helps prevent surface losses caused by excessively intense trap passivation. The hematite corrosion can initially passivate 80% of the surface deep traps, while the subsequent porous titanium layer can completely passivate the deep traps. In addition, the accurate optimization of the porous titanium layer can reconstruct the benign shallow traps on the surface, acting as superior oxygen evolution reaction active sites. This sophisticated surface-trap adjustment is accompanied by the rapid reduction of deep traps and the gradual increase of shallow traps, obtaining a superior surface state that is conducive to charge transport and interface catalysis. The obtained treated hematite yields a photocurrent density of 3.08 mA·cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE, increased by 570% compared to the pristine hematite.

elements.content: Hematite (Fe2O3) is trying to become one of the most promising semiconductor photocatalytic materials by virtue of its low cost, thermodynamic stability, and suitable band structure for light absorption and photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting. Yet, its relatively high carrier recombination rate, poor conductivity, short hole diffusion length, short carrier lifetime, and sluggish oxygen evolution reaction (OER) kinetics lead to various electron–hole recombination occurring in the bulk, interfaces, and surfaces, which further hold the PEC performance of hematite back. Among them, the surface dynamics process shows its core position of hematite and attracts extensive attention. It is well known that because of the periodic termination of the lattice and the electronic states generated by unpaired electrons that interact with each other, the surface state of the hematite will be abundant, thus leading to complex surface dynamic processes. When the photogenerated holes reach the surface, majority of the holes are trapped by the surface state, which in turn deoxidizes the water to produce oxygen (indirect transfer). Only a small portion will transmit to directly oxidize water through the valence band (direct transfer). However, it is a painful process for captured holes to participate in water oxidation, and it may be stored by trap or combine with conduction band electrons. Herein, this involves the issue of deep traps (hardly release trapped holes) and shallow traps (easily release trapped holes and participate in water oxidation).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Hematite (Fe2O3) is trying to become one of the most promising semiconductor photocatalytic materials by virtue of its low cost, thermodynamic stability, and suitable band structure for light absorption and photoelectrochemical (PEC) water splitting. Yet, its relatively high carrier recombination rate, poor conductivity, short hole diffusion length, short carrier lifetime, and sluggish oxygen evolution reaction (OER) kinetics lead to various electron-hole recombination occurring in the bulk, interfaces, and surfaces, which further hold the PEC performance of hematite back. Among them, the surface dynamics process shows its core position of hematite and attracts extensive attention. It is well known that because of the periodic termination of the lattice and the electronic states generated by unpaired electrons that interact with each other, the surface state of the hematite will be abundant, thus leading to complex surface dynamic processes. When the photogenerated holes reach the surface, majority of the holes are trapped by the surface state, which in turn deoxidizes the water to produce oxygen (indirect transfer). Only a small portion will transmit to directly oxidize water through the valence band (direct transfer). However, it is a painful process for captured holes to participate in water oxidation, and it may be stored by trap or combine with conduction band electrons. Herein, this involves the issue of deep traps (hardly release trapped holes) and shallow traps (easily release trapped holes and participate in water oxidation).

elements.content: In order to address the above issues, most researchers roughly applied surface passivation layer deposition and surface corrosion methods to eliminate surface states (traps), regardless of whether they are deep or shallow traps. This simple method does improve the efficiency of charge transfer and separation on the surface at the cost of allowing most holes to reach the surface through the valence band (direct transport), rather than through surface traps (majority of the holes are trapped by the surface state). This causes the space charge layer developing into the foundation of the charge transport process instead of the surface charge transport, which is the primary reason that the improved surface charge efficiency brings little effect on the overall performance. In addition, the indirect hole transfer is crucial for hematite because the hole-transfer step leading to water oxidation takes place predominantly from surface released holes by traps, as suggested by Klahr. Only by fine-tuning the surface traps, on the one hand, maximize the proportion of the indirect hole transmission path (building a large number of traps), and maximize the trap hole release rate on the other hand (shallow traps), can we fundamentally solve the hematite surface kinetic problems in terms of charge transport and interface water oxidation.

elements.content: The shallowing behavior cannot take into account each deep trap, resulting in a chaotic condition where deep and shallow traps coexist. Another method is to passivate the deep traps directly at first, followed by reconstruction of shallow traps. The non-negligible shortcoming of this approach is that the traps are not eliminated in reality and passively moved inward to the position close to the bulk by the passivation layer. Accordingly, these surface traps will evolve into bulk defects in the case of numerous deep traps onto hematite, hindering the internal charge transport. It is thus urgent to insert a pretreatment step before deep-trap passivation, specifically to preferentially etch away a large number of deep traps by chemical methods. With this adequate consideration, a systematic fine-tuning process of the trap state was obtained: (i) deep trap precorrosion; (ii) in-depth trap passivation; and (iii) shallow trap reconstruction.

elements.content: We were glad to find that the surface modification process of Ti-metal organic framework (MOF) can be perfectly adapted to the above three trap regulation processes. The modification process is accompanied by the reaction of the organic ligand with the FeOOH substrate and the Ti precursor and finally the in situ surface assembly of Ti-MOF. The coordination reaction between the organic ligand and the FeOOH substrate is the precorrosion of the deep traps on the surface. This precorrosion retains the terminal carboxyl group of Fe-MOF, providing the fulcrum for surface assembly. Subsequent Ti-MOF assembly achieved complete trap passivation. Interestingly, unlike the traditional compact TiO2 passivation layer, this porous Ti-MOF derivative could produce exceptional shallow traps, presenting superior active sites for water oxidation. The obtained photoanode material of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 possessed an excellent hole transport rate (20 times increase in k ct) and electron migration rate (38% decrease in electron transit time), yielding a photocurrent density of 3.08 mA·cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE, increased by 570% compared to the pristine hematite. Our work suggests a feasible route to efficiently eliminate deep traps and simultaneously promote OER kinetics for solar water oxidation.

elements.content: Fe2O3 photoanodes were synthesized by the traditional hydrothermal method and annealing process, which is reported everywhere. Briefly, the fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glasses (2 × 5 cm) were degreased by sonicating in acetone, ethanol, and distilled water for 15 min. Then, 1 M NaNO3 and 0.15 M FeCl3 were added into 50 mL of aqueous solution. HCl was added into the above solution to adjust pH to 1.25. The prepared precursor solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) for the hydrothermal reaction, into which a washed FTO glass (40 mm × 30 mm × 2 mm) was placed. The front side of FTO was faced to the bottom. The autoclave was transferred to an oven and heated at 95 °C for 12 h. The obtained FeOOH film was rinsed with deionized water for 3 min and dried at 50 °C in a gentle stream of nitrogen over 1 h, followed by thermal oxidation in air at 550 °C for 2 h and another 10 min at 700 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of Fe2O3 Photoanodes

Fe2O3 photoanodes were synthesized by the traditional hydrothermal method and annealing process, which is reported everywhere. Briefly, the fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glasses (2 × 5 cm) were degreased by sonicating in acetone, ethanol, and distilled water for 15 min. Then, 1 M NaNO3 and 0.15 M FeCl3 were added into 50 mL of aqueous solution. HCl was added into the above solution to adjust pH to 1.25. The prepared precursor solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) for the hydrothermal reaction, into which a washed FTO glass (40 mm × 30 mm × 2 mm) was placed. The front side of FTO was faced to the bottom. The autoclave was transferred to an oven and heated at 95 °C for 12 h. The obtained FeOOH film was rinsed with deionized water for 3 min and dried at 50 °C in a gentle stream of nitrogen over 1 h, followed by thermal oxidation in air at 550 °C for 2 h and another 10 min at 700 °C.

elements.content: First, a mixture of 3.0 g of terephthalic acid (BDC, Alfa, 98%), 6 mL of anhydrous MeOH, 54 mL of anhydrous N,N-dimethylmethanamide (DMF), and 0.78 mL of Ti­(OiPr)4 (Alfa, 97%) was loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL). Then, FeOOH was placed into the autoclave, and the front side of FTO was faced to the bottom. The autoclave was transferred to an oven and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained modified FeOOH was rinsed with DMF for 10 min and dried at 50 °C in a gentle stream of nitrogen over 1 h, followed by thermal oxidation in air at 550 °C for 2 h and for another 10 min at 700 °C.

Synthesis of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2

Then, FeOOH was placed into the autoclave, and the front side of FTO was faced to the bottom. The autoclave was transferred to an oven and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained modified FeOOH was rinsed with DMF for 10 min and dried at 50 °C in a gentle stream of nitrogen over 1 h, followed by thermal oxidation in air at 550 °C for 2 h and for another 10 min at 700 °C.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 

A mixture of 3.0 g of BDC (Alfa, 98%), 6 mL of anhydrous MeOH, and 54 mL of anhydrous DMF was loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL). Then, FeOOH was placed into the autoclave, and the front side of FTO was faced to the bottom. The autoclave was transferred to an oven and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained modified FeOOH was rinsed with DMF for 10 min and dried at 50 °C in a gentle stream of nitrogen for over 1 h, followed by thermal oxidation in air at 550 °C for 2 h and for another 10 min at 700 °C.

elements.content: The surface morphology was determined by field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Ultra Plus, Zeiss, Germany). The microstructure and elemental composition were investigated by transmission electronic microscopy (TEM; Tecnai G2 F30 S-TWIN, FEI, USA). The SEM and TEM both were equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray detector. X-ray diffractometry (XRD; AXS-8 Advance, Bruker, Germany) and X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS; AXIS Ultra DLD, Kratos, Japan) were applied for structural characterization. Ultraviolet (UV)–vis absorption spectra were recorded on a UV–vis spectrophotometer (TU1900, Beijing Purkinje General Instrument Co., China).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Characterization

The surface morphology was determined by field emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM; Ultra Plus, Zeiss, Germany). The microstructure and elemental composition were investigated by transmission electronic microscopy (TEM; Tecnai G2 F30 S-TWIN, FEI, USA). The SEM and TEM both were equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray detector. X-ray diffractometry (XRD; AXS-8 Advance, Bruker, Germany) and X-ray photoelectron spectrometry (XPS; AXIS Ultra DLD, Kratos, Japan) were applied for structural characterization. Ultraviolet (UV)-vis absorption spectra were recorded on a UV-vis spectrophotometer (TU1900, Beijing Purkinje General Instrument Co., China).

elements.content: The PEC water splitting measurements were conducted using a three-electrode system and an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660D, CH Instruments Inc., USA) in a 1 M KOH electrolyte. Prior to measurement, an Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode. The light source was a 350 W xenon lamp (Shanghai Hualun Bulb Factory) equipped with an AM 1.5 filter (light density, 100 mW cm–2). The potential scan rate was 50 mV s–1. The measured potentials of the Ag/AgCl electrode were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale according to the following formula: E RHE = E Ag/AgCl + 0.0591 × pH + 0.1976. The incident photon-to-charge conversion efficiency (IPCE) was measured using a monochromator (Zolix, China) equipped with a 500 W xenon arc lamp, a calibrated silicon photodetector, and a power meter. IPCE data were collected from 300 to 700 nm at 1.23 V versus RHE. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed using the same electrochemical workstation and a three-electrode system used for the photocurrent measurements with the following testing conditions: amplitude perturbations of 5 mV, a frequency range of 1 Hz to 10 kHz, and specific direct current constant potentials (0.7–1.3 V vs RHE). Nyquist plots were fitted to the selected equivalent circuits (ECs) using the ZSimpWin software (vs 3.10). Mott–Schottky plots were obtained from 0 to 2 V versus RHE at 1 kHz in the dark. Intensity-modulated photocurrent spectroscopy (IMPS) was performed using an electrochemical workstation (Zennium; effect-Elektrik, Germany) coupled with a controlled IMPS setup (PP211) and a white-light lamp (WLC02; Zahner-Elektrik) whose DC illumination was adjusted to 80 mW/cm2. The same three-electrode configuration was used. Modulated light in the frequency range of 0.1–10 kHz was applied.

PEC Measurements

The PEC water splitting measurements were conducted using a three-electrode system and an electrochemical workstation (CHI 660D, CH Instruments Inc., USA) in a 1 M KOH electrolyte. Prior to measurement, an Ag/AgCl electrode was used as the reference electrode. The light source was a 350 W xenon lamp (Shanghai Hualun Bulb Factory) equipped with an AM 1.5 filter (light density, 100 mW cm-2). The potential scan rate was 50 mV s-1. The measured potentials of the Ag/AgCl electrode were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale according to the following formula: E RHE = E Ag/AgCl + 0.0591 × pH + 0.1976. The incident photon-to-charge conversion efficiency (IPCE) was measured using a monochromator (Zolix, China) equipped with a 500 W xenon arc lamp, a calibrated silicon photodetector, and a power meter. IPCE data were collected from 300 to 700 nm at 1.23 V versus RHE. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was performed using the same electrochemical workstation and a three-electrode system used for the photocurrent measurements with the following testing conditions: amplitude perturbations of 5 mV, a frequency range of 1 Hz to 10 kHz, and specific direct current constant potentials (0.7-1.3 V vs RHE). Nyquist plots were fitted to the selected equivalent circuits (ECs) using the ZSimpWin software (vs 3.10). Mott-Schottky plots were obtained from 0 to 2 V versus RHE at 1 kHz in the dark. Intensity-modulated photocurrent spectroscopy (IMPS) was performed using an electrochemical workstation (Zennium; effect-Elektrik, Germany) coupled with a controlled IMPS setup (PP211) and a white-light lamp (WLC02; Zahner-Elektrik) whose DC illumination was adjusted to 80 mW/cm2. elements.content: In order to gain an accurate insight into the MOF-induced impact on the surface trap distribution, we followed a bottom-up analysis strategy, starting with microstructures and effectively wrapping up subsequent investigations over traps from the inside out. On the basis of hydrothermally prepared hematite, a one-step reaction of MOF and subsequent calcination were used to synchronously generate a double-layer modification of M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 on the hematite surface, forming a sandwich-like photoanode material of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2. At first, we tracked the trace of the hydrothermal process at different reaction times. a–e shows the SEM images of the as-grown uncalcined photoelectrode from 0 to 24 h. As shown in a, the individual vertically erected FeOOH NRs are approximately 100 nm in diameter, decreasing to about 50 nm with extended hydrothermal reaction time from 0 to 8 h (b,c). This apparent surface chemical corrosion is possibly caused by the excess BDC (1,4-BDC) which could react with iron-oxo clusters to form MIL-53­(Fe). The TEM image (Figure S2) shows that a porous layer of about 5 nm is formed on the surface, which is probably the result of the corrosion by 1,4-BDC. Coupled with f, it can be seen that MIL-53­(Fe) was successfully synthesized, but most of it fell out of the precursor solution (Figure S1). At the same time, additional 1,4-BDC reacts with Isopropyl titanate (Ti­(OiPr)4) under high-temperature hydrothermal conditions to form MIL-125­(Ti) in the precursor solution. At this moment, the self-assembled materials (MIL-125­(Ti)) and connection sites (terminal carboxyl of residual MIL-53­(Fe)) are ready. Once enough carboxyl sites are exposed on the surface, a large amount of MIL-125­(Ti) in the precursor solution can easily grow on the corroded FeOOH surface. The gradual growth of MIL-125­(Ti) with the duration of the hydrothermal reaction can be seen in Figure S3a–c. As-formed MIL-125­(Ti) thus can be assembled at the terminal carboxyl of MIL-53­(Fe) from 12 to 24 h (d,e) because the NRs in c–e become thicker and many tree-like structures grow on the surface of a single nanorod. Further TEM images of hydrothermally treated photoanodes before and after calcination are shown in Figure S3. As shown in Figure S3a–c, the porous flocs on the surface of FeOOH NRs gradually increase with the duration of the hydrothermal reaction, indicating that the surface self-assembly process is continuing. Combining the element distribution of the Ti element in d and the characteristic peak of MIL-125­(Ti) in f can further prove the successful self-assembly process of MIL-125­(Ti) on the FeOOH surface. In addition, the XRD patterns of samples with different hydrothermal times confirmed our speculation that the 8 h sample had a significant characteristic peak of MIL-53­(Fe) at 12.2°, indicating that the surface BDC corrosion process was successfully carried out (f, green line, CCDC: 690315). The characteristic peaks of MIL-125­(Ti) at 6.9 and 9.9° for the following 24 h sample confirmed the realization of the surface self-assembly (f, red line, CCDC: 751157). Therefore, we proposed a brand-new self-assembly mechanism of the hydrothermal reaction process illustrated in g (the structures of MIL-125­(Ti) and MIL-53­(Fe) are shown in Figure S4). The whole self-assembly behavior involves two parallel processes in the first 12 h, while the last 12 h of the hydrothermal reaction is the time for surface self-assembly.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthetic Insight: Parallel Assembly and Ligand Linkage

In order to gain an accurate insight into the MOF-induced impact on the surface trap distribution, we followed a bottom-up analysis strategy, starting with microstructures and effectively wrapping up subsequent investigations over traps from the inside out. On the basis of hydrothermally prepared hematite, a one-step reaction of MOF and subsequent calcination were used to synchronously generate a double-layer modification of M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 on the hematite surface, forming a sandwich-like photoanode material of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2. At first, we tracked the trace of the hydrothermal process at different reaction times. a-e shows the SEM images of the as-grown uncalcined photoelectrode from 0 to 24 h. As shown in a, the individual vertically erected FeOOH NRs are approximately 100 nm in diameter, decreasing to about 50 nm with extended hydrothermal reaction time from 0 to 8 h (b,c). This apparent surface chemical corrosion is possibly caused by the excess BDC (1,4-BDC) which could react with iron-oxo clusters to form MIL-53(Fe). The TEM image (Figure S2) shows that a porous layer of about 5 nm is formed on the surface, which is probably the result of the corrosion by 1,4-BDC. Coupled with f, it can be seen that MIL-53(Fe) was successfully synthesized, but most of it fell out of the precursor solution (Figure S1). At the same time, additional 1,4-BDC reacts with Isopropyl titanate (Ti(OiPr)4) under high-temperature hydrothermal conditions to form MIL-125(Ti) in the precursor solution. At this moment, the self-assembled materials (MIL-125(Ti)) and connection sites (terminal carboxyl of residual MIL-53(Fe)) are ready. Once enough carboxyl sites are exposed on the surface, a large amount of MIL-125(Ti) in the precursor solution can easily grow on the corroded FeOOH surface. The gradual growth of MIL-125(Ti) with the duration of the hydrothermal reaction can be seen in Figure S3a-c. As-formed MIL-125(Ti) thus can be assembled at the terminal carboxyl of MIL-53(Fe) from 12 to 24 h (d,e) because the NRs in c-e become thicker and many tree-like structures grow on the surface of a single nanorod. Further TEM images of hydrothermally treated photoanodes before and after calcination are shown in Figure S3. As shown in Figure S3a-c, the porous flocs on the surface of FeOOH NRs gradually increase with the duration of the hydrothermal reaction, indicating that the surface self-assembly process is continuing. Combining the element distribution of the Ti element in d and the characteristic peak of MIL-125(Ti) in f can further prove the successful self-assembly process of MIL-125(Ti) on the FeOOH surface. In addition, the XRD patterns of samples with different hydrothermal times confirmed our speculation that the 8 h sample had a significant characteristic peak of MIL-53(Fe) at 12.2°, indicating that the surface BDC corrosion process was successfully carried out (f, green line, CCDC: 690315). The characteristic peaks of MIL-125(Ti) at 6.9 and 9.9° for the following 24 h sample confirmed the realization of the surface self-assembly (f, red line, CCDC: 751157). Therefore, we proposed a brand-new self-assembly mechanism of the hydrothermal reaction process illustrated in g (the structures of MIL-125(Ti) and MIL-53(Fe) are shown in Figure S4). The whole self-assembly behavior involves two parallel processes in the first 12 h, while the last 12 h of the hydrothermal reaction is the time for surface self-assembly.

elements.content: Sufficient calcination treatment can convert FeOOH/MIL-53­(Fe)/MIL-125­(Ti) into Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2. To figure out the thermal treatment mechanism, morphological, structural, and surface analyses were thoroughly carried out to elucidate the microscopic changes hidden under observable macrobehavior. First, SEM images were obtained for pristine FeOOH and hematite, as well as FeOOH/MIL-53­(Fe)/MIL-125­(Ti) and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 (a,a′,b,b′). With the high-temperature thermal treatment, the surface morphology became smooth because of high-temperature dehydration and dehydrogenation (a′,b′). Compared to the pristine hematite, the treated hematite (b) consists of the finer and compact particles as a result of the surface chemical corrosion and self-assembly process. The corresponding TEM images for a′,b′ are shown in c,d, indicating that chemical corrosion effectively reduced the particle size of the optimal sample, down to around 50 nm in diameter (Figure S5). In addition, simultaneous thermal conversion brings a uniform porous structure (d), leading to a higher UV adsorption coefficient (Figure S6). Additionally, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of the optimal Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 given in d′ exhibits three phases in composition, in which the left region represents the surface MOF-derived TiO2 (e) and the right region represents the corroded Fe2O3 (f), whereas the intermediate ribbon region may represent the hematite converted by the small amount of MIL-53­(Fe). Interestingly, the presence of Fe2TiO5 in f demonstrates that Ti diffuses into Fe2O3 under high-temperature calcination to form Ti–O–Fe bonds, as confirmed by the negative shift of the Ti 2p peak displayed in i. Additionally, the XPS spectrum suggested that the C 1s peak of FeOOH/MIL-53­(Fe)/MIL-125­(Ti) can be deconvoluted into three peaks centered at 284.2, 284.9, and 288.6 eV, corresponding to the C–C/CC, C–C, and CO bonds, respectively. The disappearance of the CO peak revealed that the link between the benzene ring and the metal ion is completely broken (in metal–organic ligands, the connection between carbon and metal is mediated by oxygen in this work). Similarly, the O 1s peak was divided into three peaks located in 530.1, 531.5, and 532.5 eV, which can be assigned to Fe–O/Ti–O, CO, and −OH, respectively. The CO peak disappeared, whereas the intensity of the Fe–O/Ti–O peak increases significantly, implying that almost all oxygen is associated with iron and titanium.
elements.clean_text: Sufficient calcination treatment can convert FeOOH/MIL-53(Fe)/MIL-125(Ti) into Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2. To figure out the thermal treatment mechanism, morphological, structural, and surface analyses were thoroughly carried out to elucidate the microscopic changes hidden under observable macrobehavior. First, SEM images were obtained for pristine FeOOH and hematite, as well as FeOOH/MIL-53(Fe)/MIL-125(Ti) and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 (a,a',b,b'). With the high-temperature thermal treatment, the surface morphology became smooth because of high-temperature dehydration and dehydrogenation (a',b'). Compared to the pristine hematite, the treated hematite (b) consists of the finer and compact particles as a result of the surface chemical corrosion and self-assembly process. The corresponding TEM images for a',b' are shown in c,d, indicating that chemical corrosion effectively reduced the particle size of the optimal sample, down to around 50 nm in diameter (Figure S5). In addition, simultaneous thermal conversion brings a uniform porous structure (d), leading to a higher UV adsorption coefficient (Figure S6). Additionally, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of the optimal Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 given in d' exhibits three phases in composition, in which the left region represents the surface MOF-derived TiO2 (e) and the right region represents the corroded Fe2O3 (f), whereas the intermediate ribbon region may represent the hematite converted by the small amount of MIL-53(Fe). Interestingly, the presence of Fe2TiO5 in f demonstrates that Ti diffuses into Fe2O3 under high-temperature calcination to form Ti-O-Fe bonds, as confirmed by the negative shift of the Ti 2p peak displayed in i. Additionally, the XPS spectrum suggested that the C 1s peak of FeOOH/MIL-53(Fe)/MIL-125(Ti) can be deconvoluted into three peaks centered at 284.2, 284.9, and 288.6 eV, corresponding to the C-C/CC, C-C, and CO bonds, respectively. The disappearance of the CO peak revealed that the link between the benzene ring and the metal ion is completely broken (in metal-organic ligands, the connection between carbon and metal is mediated by oxygen in this work). Similarly, the O 1s peak was divided into three peaks located in 530.1, 531.5, and 532.5 eV, which can be assigned to Fe-O/Ti-O, CO, and -OH, respectively. The CO peak disappeared, whereas the intensity of the Fe-O/Ti-O peak increases significantly, implying that almost all oxygen is associated with iron and titanium.

elements.content: A preliminary understanding of the photoactivity over Fe2O3, Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3, and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 photoanodes was obtained by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) measurement (a). M-Fe2O3 modification increased the photocurrent density of pristine hematite at 1.23 VRHE from 0.46 to 0.96 mA·cm–2, which was more than doubled. The combination of M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 further increased the photocurrent to 3.08 mA·cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE, 5.7 times higher than that of pristine hematite. We found that the MOF-induced photoactivity is extremely sensitive to the concentration fluctuations, especially 1,4-BDC. As given in b, the photocurrent density increased with the rise of the Ti­(OiPr)4 concentration, reaching maximum at 0.78g/60 mL, whereas further increase in the concentration led to a decrease in the photocurrent. This proves to be an optimal concentration of Ti­(OiPr)4 where excessive or insufficient M-TiO2 is not conducive to the charge transport of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 (Figure S12). In addition, it was found that the photoanode was very strongly dependent on 1,4-BDC observed in c. Starting from 3 g/60 mL, the photocurrent density of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 decreases from 3.08 to 1.2 mA·cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE, and when it comes to 2 g/60 mL, the photocurrent density decreased by 61%. This revealed that 1,4-BDC must reach an excess, in line with the results of the aforementioned morphological characterization (Figures S8–S10). As we can see, d shows the comparison of the PEC performance when the hydrothermal substrate is converted from FeOOH to Fe2O3 by calcination (AHA-Fe2O3/TiO2). It is worth noting that AHA-Fe2O3/TiO2 shows a markedly reduced photocurrent density and increasing onset potential, suggesting the essential role of the substrate FeOOH’s ability to interact with 1,4-BDC, in accordance with the SEM characterization results (Figure S13).

elements.content: In view of the above structural characterization and its influence on the PEC performance, we can track the trace of every component from the inside out upon Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2. Before our investigation, the internal characteristics of hematite should be mentioned, that is, severe interface hole trapping behavior caused by the termination of the internal periodic structure, yielding a strong surface state density which plays a prominent role in the water oxidation reaction. This surface state behavior may involve an interface iron atom oxidation process [Fe­(II), Fe­(III), Fe­(IV), Fe­(V), Fe­(VI)], structural transformation of surface-adsorbed oxygen, or capacitance characteristics of iron oxyhydroxide (ferrihydrate). In order to investigate the effect of the M-Fe2O3 layer on the surface of hematite, we used excess of 1,4-BDC (3 g/60 mL) to etch hematite surface without any Ti­(OiPr)4 and utilized this electrode as the research protype.
elements.clean_text:
Primary Regulation: Partial Passivation of Surface Traps

In view of the above structural characterization and its influence on the PEC performance, we can track the trace of every component from the inside out upon Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2. Before our investigation, the internal characteristics of hematite should be mentioned, that is, severe interface hole trapping behavior caused by the termination of the internal periodic structure, yielding a strong surface state density which plays a prominent role in the water oxidation reaction. This surface state behavior may involve an interface iron atom oxidation process [Fe(II), Fe(III), Fe(IV), Fe(V), Fe(VI)], structural transformation of surface-adsorbed oxygen, or capacitance characteristics of iron oxyhydroxide (ferrihydrate). In order to investigate the effect of the M-Fe2O3 layer on the surface of hematite, we used excess of 1,4-BDC (3 g/60 mL) to etch hematite surface without any Ti(OiPr)4 and utilized this electrode as the research protype.

elements.content: In this work, the prepared pristine hematite suffered from rigorous surface hole trapping and hole accumulation by high-valence iron as confirmed by a (peak located at 1.5 VRHE), as well as the weaker trapping by water oxidation intermediate (a, peak located at 0.9 VRHE), evidencing substantial surface hole storage by high-valence iron and sluggish trapped hole reaction kinetics in the photoresponse stage. The significant hole accumulation phenomenon at high potential is not due to the weak hole release ability of trap at 1.5 VRHE rather than the extremely large amount of surface high-valence iron distribution (a large amount of high-valence iron is formed by the significant oxygen enrichment on the surface) which aggravates the hole accumulation phenomenon. In addition, the surface state at 0.9 VRHE is capable of oxidizing water thermodynamically because the produced photovoltage by hematite should be added (Figure S15). Surface corrosion by excessive 1,4-BDC notably passivates the reduction peak at 1.5 VRHE by nearly an order of magnitude (decreased by 80%), indicating that a large amount of surface high-valence iron structures are removed. However, the obtained surface M-Fe2O3 is not the ideal contact surface for water oxidation, as a slight expanding phenomenon could be observed in the corresponding cyclic voltammetry (CV) curve with increasing scan rate, denoting the incomplete removal of high-valence iron structures.

elements.content: In addition, this corrosion behavior is also detected in photo-electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (PEIS) plots of the finest 1,4-BDC-treated hematite with different bias potentials (c,d), that is, an enlarged capacitive reactance arc (two-time constants are stacked together, d), understood as a typical feature of localized corrosion of the electrode surface. This corrosion process drastically reduces the diameter of the capacitive reactance arc, achieving a larger surface state capacitance and lower charge transfer resistance compared to the pristine (shown in Figure S14). Similar conclusions can be drawn from Bode plots, as shown in Figure S16, that surface corrosion substantially eliminates peaks in the low-frequency region (2 Hz) of bare hematite, removing surface impurities. Consequently, surface corrosion via 1,4-BDC decreases the detrimental trap states and simultaneously increases the rate of surface state transport at lower potential.

elements.content: The above-mentioned corrosion effects on surface traps significantly change the surface reaction kinetics, observed in the chopped LSV method, as shown in e. For the sake of understanding, we recognized the transient current value as the difference between the amount of hole trapping and release, viz., the amount of hole accumulation. As given in e from 0.8 to 1.4 VRHE, the original hematite always shows the constant and larger transient current density, pointing out that the deteriorated hole accumulation phenomenon does not change with potential, accompanied by severe surface Fermi level pinning effects. The M-Fe2O3 layer (surface corrosion) shortens the transient current response range (0.8–1.2 VRHE), showing an obvious Gaussian distribution characteristic (the largest at 1 VRHE and gradually decreases on both sides). This revealed that the hole accumulation behavior is gradually sensitive to the bias potential through the trap-state adjustment described previously. On the other hand, the coating layer shifts the electrocatalysis OER onset potential to more positive potential. This apparent effect might be related to the increased photovoltage and the weakened Fermi level pinning effect. Accordingly, the first step surface corrosion significantly eliminated the high-potential trap caused by high-valence iron and accelerated the surface reaction kinetics at lower potential (Figure S17, reduced Tafel slope).

elements.content: The surface shallow trap activation is not fulfilled, still exhibiting a large number of hole accumulation due to surface defects, as shown in e (obvious transient spikes, red line). A part of surface deep traps stems from the original deep trap that has not been eliminated, and the other part stems from the secondary defects caused by surface corrosion. The self-assembly onto terminal carboxyl overcomes this potential surface secondary trap to the greatest extent because the atoms at the interface between M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 are regularly arranged without disorderly arrangement. The tight connection of the M-TiO2 and M-Fe2O3 would function as an electron transport channel, thereby accelerating the charge transfer of hematite. The IMPS plot was thus applied to measure the charge transit time (τ) in the hematite films, followed by the following equation: τ = (2πf)−1, where f is the value of minimal frequency in the IMPS plots. As shown in a, the obtained values of f corresponding to Fe2O3, Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3, and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 are 5.123, 4.364, and 6.975 Hz, and thus, τ values were calculated to be 31.1, 36.5, and 22.8 ms, respectively. The largest τ for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 demonstrated that photogenerated electrons more hardly reach the back contact, which may be caused by reintroduced surface traps in M-Fe2O3. The introduction of M-TiO2 not only constructs a well-interconnected interface but also greatly reduces the transmission resistance, thus accelerating the electron transfer, confirmed by the minimum value of τ for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2.
elements.clean_text:
Avoidance of Secondary Defects: Tight Interface Connection

The surface shallow trap activation is not fulfilled, still exhibiting a large number of hole accumulation due to surface defects, as shown in e (obvious transient spikes, red line). A part of surface deep traps stems from the original deep trap that has not been eliminated, and the other part stems from the secondary defects caused by surface corrosion. The self-assembly onto terminal carboxyl overcomes this potential surface secondary trap to the greatest extent because the atoms at the interface between M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 are regularly arranged without disorderly arrangement. The tight connection of the M-TiO2 and M-Fe2O3 would function as an electron transport channel, thereby accelerating the charge transfer of hematite. The IMPS plot was thus applied to measure the charge transit time (τ) in the hematite films, followed by the following equation: τ = (2πf)-1, where f is the value of minimal frequency in the IMPS plots. As shown in a, the obtained values of f corresponding to Fe2O3, Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3, and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 are 5.123, 4.364, and 6.975 Hz, and thus, τ values were calculated to be 31.1, 36.5, and 22.8 ms, respectively. The largest τ for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 demonstrated that photogenerated electrons more hardly reach the back contact, which may be caused by reintroduced surface traps in M-Fe2O3. The introduction of M-TiO2 not only constructs a well-interconnected interface but also greatly reduces the transmission resistance, thus accelerating the electron transfer, confirmed by the minimum value of τ for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2.

elements.content: On the other hand, we obtained the PEIS plots of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 (b) and displayed them in the form of Bode plots at different potentials (c) to verify the transport state of holes. By comparison with Bode plots of Fe2O3 and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 shown in Figure S16, the position of the low-frequency peaks is slightly shifted to the high frequency (from ∼1 to ∼3 Hz), mainly because of inward shift of defect states caused by covering of the original hematite surface by a permeable M-TiO2 layer. At low potential, the holes in the hematite did not successfully transfer to the TiO2 layer, reflected in the unchanging peak at ∼3 Hz below 0.8 VRHE. Nevertheless, starting from 0.8 VRHE, the peak intensity at ∼3 Hz decreases rapidly and then reaches a steady state at 1 VRHE, yielding a drastically increasing charge-transfer constant (k ct) of optimal Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 (d, 0.8–1 VRHE). This extremely rapid growth trend is reflected in the Tafel slope of the photocurrent density (e), indicating that the tight interface structure provides the foundation for hole transport. Through the MOF induction process, the phase angle of the limit step at 3 Hz is lower than 20° at 1 VRHE, smaller than 41° of pure hematite and 30° of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3, indicating that the presence of M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 coordinately inhibits the source of inward surface traps of the original hematite. In summary, we summarized the reasons for the high-speed hole transport of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 prepared under optimal conditions: M-Fe2O3 first etched and passivated the original hematite surface and optimized the harsh surface state to a certain extent but not fulfilled, simultaneously creating conditions for the further M-TiO2 modification; the modification of M-TiO2 moved the original optimized surface defects internally, plus the fabulous interface bonding of M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 and superior hole transmission performance of M-TiO2 itself, leading to its remarkable hole transport performance (although the inward defect center still dominates below 0.8 VRHE). Herein, the charge accumulation at ultralow potential (below 0.8 VRHE) of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 may be our next research direction to achieve its lower onset potential for hematite.

elements.content: This fast charge transfer is also clearly emerged in the transient photocurrent test (Figure S18) by converting it to a standardized parameter D via the following formula: D = (J t – J ss)/(J in – J ss), where J t , J ss, and J in are time-dependent, steady-state, and instantaneous photocurrent density, respectively (the value of J t , J ss, and J in are listed in Figure S18). As shown in f (black line), the appearance of attenuation peaks between 10–4 and 10–3 s shows that the charge transfer of hematite occurs slowly near the surface. Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 shows an extremely abrupt attenuation parameter, demonstrating an accelerated tendency as time scales widen. That means the closer the hole is to the surface, the faster is the transfer rate.

elements.content: The surface M-TiO2 constructed a completely different surface state, not only completely passivating the previous high-potential traps but also reconstructing the low-potential traps on the surface. The CV curves (a,b) show the difference in the surface state between the optimal Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 and the specific Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 (Ti­(OiPr)4, 0.156 mL per 60 mL), of which the CV curve of the latter possessed no accumulation phenomenon (passivate the reduction peak at 1.5 VRHE, reducing it by more than 95% compared to pristine hematite), demonstrating that only a small amount of M-TiO2 can entirely passivate the remaining surface traps of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3. Unlike the single passivation effect of compact TiO2 on hematite (see f), the unique porous structure of M-TiO2 in this work can passivate the surface of hematite while constructing new benign shallow traps (the reduction peak at 0.9 VRHE). In addition, the reduction peak at 0.9 VRHE gradually increases with the rise of Ti­(OiPr)4 concentration (as shown in b–e) until the Ti­(OiPr)4 concentration is 0.78/60 mL. Further increase in the concentration of Ti­(OiPr)4 did not bring about an increase in the intensity of the reduction peak, implying that the assembled surface M-TiO2 tends to be saturated. Moreover, the sample of 0.78/60 mL shows the greatest current density, as shown in c, indicating that saturated benign surface traps play a predominate role on water oxidation at lower potential. An additional increase of M-TiO2 suppresses the increase in the PEC performance possibly because excessively thicker surface M-TiO2 hinders internal Fe2O3 light absorption or hole quantum tunneling effect.

Ultimate Processing: Complete Passivation and Shallow Trap Reconstruction

The surface M-TiO2 constructed a completely different surface state, not only completely passivating the previous high-potential traps but also reconstructing the low-potential traps on the surface. The CV curves (a,b) show the difference in the surface state between the optimal Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 and the specific Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 (Ti(OiPr)4, 0.156 mL per 60 mL), of which the CV curve of the latter possessed no accumulation phenomenon (passivate the reduction peak at 1.5 VRHE, reducing it by more than 95% compared to pristine hematite), demonstrating that only a small amount of M-TiO2 can entirely passivate the remaining surface traps of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3. Unlike the single passivation effect of compact TiO2 on hematite (see f), the unique porous structure of M-TiO2 in this work can passivate the surface of hematite while constructing new benign shallow traps (the reduction peak at 0.9 VRHE). In addition, the reduction peak at 0.9 VRHE gradually increases with the rise of Ti(OiPr)4 concentration (as shown in b-e) until the Ti(OiPr)4 concentration is 0.78/60 mL. Further increase in the concentration of Ti(OiPr)4 did not bring about an increase in the intensity of the reduction peak, implying that the assembled surface M-TiO2 tends to be saturated. Moreover, the sample of 0.78/60 mL shows the greatest current density, as shown in c, indicating that saturated benign surface traps play a predominate role on water oxidation at lower potential. An additional increase of M-TiO2 suppresses the increase in the PEC performance possibly because excessively thicker surface M-TiO2 hinders internal Fe2O3 light absorption or hole quantum tunneling effect.

elements.content: Generally, the deep trap is a strong negative charge center, which possesses a strong ability to trap holes, forming a more stable state and not easy to release holes. The slower kinetic process is reflected in the slower transient peak decay rate and the slow growth of the CV reduction peak (e and a). As opposed to deep traps, shallow traps are weak negative charge centers with an unstable state, as reflected in the fast transient peak decay rate and no accumulation of CV (b, e, and ).

elements.content: In summary, we are successful in fabricating MOF-derived M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 via in situ one-step growth onto Fe2O3 NRs, for the efficient hole is transfer achieved by surface trap reshaping. It has been proved by multiple hydrothermal experiments that the self-assembly process goes through two stages: the first stage consists of 1,4-BDC that reacts with isopropyl titanate or FeOOH NRs to form corresponding MOF (0–12 h) and the second stage is the self-assembly stage (12–24 h). SEM and TEM images indicate the important bridging role of ligand 1,4-BDC, suggesting that excessive 1,4-BDC is quite essential. CV and Nyquist plots show that the surface corrosion caused by 1,4-BDC significantly eliminates the high-potential trap near the valence band. PEIS fitting and transient current demonstrated that MOF-derived TiO2 significantly improves the intrinsic properties of the surface, facilitating electron–hole transport. Unlike compact TiO2 films, porous permeable TiO2 introduces an appropriate amount of superior surface defects, which further enhances the surface catalytic activity in the photoresponse stage. The resulting precision structure will have the following original characteristics: (i) the organic acid ligand erodes hematite form, labeled [MIL-53­(Fe), M-Fe2O3] while tightly bonding iron and titanium avoiding the secondary structural defects; (ii) after heat treatment, the high-quality surface state is reconstructed by the porous TiO2, further passivating the deep traps directly; (iii) the surface MOF-derived TiO2 forms a remarkable porous permeable morphology, which greatly enhances the surface oxygen evolution kinetics. All of these advantages for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 result in a photocurrent density of 3.08 mA cm–2 without any oxygen evolution catalyst, increased by 570% compared to pristine hematite. Our work suggests a path forward to design and construct improved electrodes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we are successful in fabricating MOF-derived M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 via in situ one-step growth onto Fe2O3 NRs, for the efficient hole is transfer achieved by surface trap reshaping. It has been proved by multiple hydrothermal experiments that the self-assembly process goes through two stages: the first stage consists of 1,4-BDC that reacts with isopropyl titanate or FeOOH NRs to form corresponding MOF (0-12 h) and the second stage is the self-assembly stage (12-24 h). SEM and TEM images indicate the important bridging role of ligand 1,4-BDC, suggesting that excessive 1,4-BDC is quite essential. CV and Nyquist plots show that the surface corrosion caused by 1,4-BDC significantly eliminates the high-potential trap near the valence band. PEIS fitting and transient current demonstrated that MOF-derived TiO2 significantly improves the intrinsic properties of the surface, facilitating electron-hole transport. Unlike compact TiO2 films, porous permeable TiO2 introduces an appropriate amount of superior surface defects, which further enhances the surface catalytic activity in the photoresponse stage. The resulting precision structure will have the following original characteristics: (i) the organic acid ligand erodes hematite form, labeled [MIL-53(Fe), M-Fe2O3] while tightly bonding iron and titanium avoiding the secondary structural defects; (ii) after heat treatment, the high-quality surface state is reconstructed by the porous TiO2, further passivating the deep traps directly; (iii) the surface MOF-derived TiO2 forms a remarkable porous permeable morphology, which greatly enhances the surface oxygen evolution kinetics. All of these advantages for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 result in a photocurrent density of 3.08 mA cm-2 without any oxygen evolution catalyst, increased by 570% compared to pristine hematite. Our work suggests a path forward to design and construct improved electrodes.

cln_elements.content:
Fe2O3 photoanodes were synthesized by the traditional hydrothermal method and annealing process, which is reported everywhere. Briefly, the fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glasses (2 × 5 cm) were degreased by sonicating in acetone, ethanol, and distilled water for 15 min. Then, 1 M NaNO3 and 0.15 M FeCl3 were added into 50 mL of aqueous solution. HCl was added into the above solution to adjust pH to 1.25. The prepared precursor solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) for the hydrothermal reaction, into which a washed FTO glass (40 mm × 30 mm × 2 mm) was placed. The front side of FTO was faced to the bottom. The autoclave was transferred to an oven and heated at 95 °C for 12 h. The obtained FeOOH film was rinsed with deionized water for 3 min and dried at 50 °C in a gentle stream of nitrogen over 1 h, followed by thermal oxidation in air at 550 °C for 2 h and another 10 min at 700 °C.

Synthesis of Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/M-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/M-TiO<sub>2</sub>

First, a mixture of 3.0 g of terephthalic acid (BDC, Alfa, 98%), 6 mL of anhydrous MeOH, 54 mL of anhydrous N,N-dimethylmethanamide (DMF), and 0.78 mL of Ti­(OiPr)4 (Alfa, 97%) was loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL). Then, FeOOH was placed into the autoclave, and the front side of FTO was faced to the bottom. The autoclave was transferred to an oven and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained modified FeOOH was rinsed with DMF for 10 min and dried at 50 °C in a gentle stream of nitrogen over 1 h, followed by thermal oxidation in air at 550 °C for 2 h and for another 10 min at 700 °C.

Synthesis of Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/M-Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>

A mixture of 3.0 g of BDC (Alfa, 98%), 6 mL of anhydrous MeOH, and 54 mL of anhydrous DMF was loaded into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL). Then, FeOOH was placed into the autoclave, and the front side of FTO was faced to the bottom. The autoclave was transferred to an oven and heated at 120 °C for 24 h. The obtained modified FeOOH was rinsed with DMF for 10 min and dried at 50 °C in a gentle stream of nitrogen for over 1 h, followed by thermal oxidation in air at 550 °C for 2 h and for another 10 min at 700 °C.

Experimental Section

Synthesis of Fe2O3 Photoanodes

Fe2O3 photoanodes were synthesized by the traditional hydrothermal method and annealing process, which is reported everywhere. Briefly, the fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) glasses (2 × 5 cm) were degreased by sonicating in acetone, ethanol, and distilled water for 15 min. Then, 1 M NaNO3 and 0.15 M FeCl3 were added into 50 mL of aqueous solution. HCl was added into the above solution to adjust pH to 1.25. The prepared precursor solution was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) for the hydrothermal reaction, into which a washed FTO glass (40 mm × 30 mm × 2 mm) was placed. cln_elements.content:
Complex surface dynamics is the key to limit the photoelectrochemical performance of hematite, while its core content is the hole trapping and release by surface traps. Deep traps are accompanied by extremely fast capture rates and extremely slow release rates, which severely suppress the hole transport process. Herein, we proposed a unique method to progressively convert deep traps on the hematite surface for fast hole transfer via in situ one-step metal organic framework modification. This stepwise deep-trap passivation is achieved by hematite corrosion first on the surface and subsequent construction of a porous titanium layer. The gentle trap finishing helps prevent surface losses caused by excessively intense trap passivation. The hematite corrosion can initially passivate 80% of the surface deep traps, while the subsequent porous titanium layer can completely passivate the deep traps. In addition, the accurate optimization of the porous titanium layer can reconstruct the benign shallow traps on the surface, acting as superior oxygen evolution reaction active sites. This sophisticated surface-trap adjustment is accompanied by the rapid reduction of deep traps and the gradual increase of shallow traps, obtaining a superior surface state that is conducive to charge transport and interface catalysis. The obtained treated hematite yields a photocurrent density of 3.08 mA·cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE, increased by 570% compared to the pristine hematite.

Macroscopic Presentation: Sensitivity to Concentration Fluctuations

A preliminary understanding of the photoactivity over Fe2O3, Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3, and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 photoanodes was obtained by linear scanning voltammetry (LSV) measurement (a). M-Fe2O3 modification increased the photocurrent density of pristine hematite at 1.23 VRHE from 0.46 to 0.96 mA·cm–2, which was more than doubled. The combination of M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 further increased the photocurrent to 3.08 mA·cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE, 5.7 times higher than that of pristine hematite. We found that the MOF-induced photoactivity is extremely sensitive to the concentration fluctuations, especially 1,4-BDC. As given in b, the photocurrent density increased with the rise of the Ti­(OiPr)4 concentration, reaching maximum at 0.78g/60 mL, whereas further increase in the concentration led to a decrease in the photocurrent. This proves to be an optimal concentration of Ti­(OiPr)4 where excessive or insufficient M-TiO2 is not conducive to the charge transport of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 (Figure S12). In addition, it was found that the photoanode was very strongly dependent on 1,4-BDC observed in c. Starting from 3 g/60 mL, the photocurrent density of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 decreases from 3.08 to 1.2 mA·cm–2 at 1.23 VRHE, and when it comes to 2 g/60 mL, the photocurrent density decreased by 61%. This revealed that 1,4-BDC must reach an excess, in line with the results of the aforementioned morphological characterization (Figures S8–S10). As we can see, d shows the comparison of the PEC performance when the hydrothermal substrate is converted from FeOOH to Fe2O3 by calcination (AHA-Fe2O3/TiO2). It is worth noting that AHA-Fe2O3/TiO2 shows a markedly reduced photocurrent density and increasing onset potential, suggesting the essential role of the substrate FeOOH’s ability to interact with 1,4-BDC, in accordance with the SEM characterization results (Figure S13).

Avoidance of Secondary Defects: Tight Interface Connection

The surface shallow trap activation is not fulfilled, still exhibiting a large number of hole accumulation due to surface defects, as shown in e (obvious transient spikes, red line). A part of surface deep traps stems from the original deep trap that has not been eliminated, and the other part stems from the secondary defects caused by surface corrosion. The self-assembly onto terminal carboxyl overcomes this potential surface secondary trap to the greatest extent because the atoms at the interface between M-Fe2O3 and M-TiO2 are regularly arranged without disorderly arrangement. The tight connection of the M-TiO2 and M-Fe2O3 would function as an electron transport channel, thereby accelerating the charge transfer of hematite. The IMPS plot was thus applied to measure the charge transit time (τ) in the hematite films, followed by the following equation: τ = (2πf)−1, where f is the value of minimal frequency in the IMPS plots. As shown in a, the obtained values of f corresponding to Fe2O3, Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3, and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 are 5.123, 4.364, and 6.975 Hz, and thus, τ values were calculated to be 31.1, 36.5, and 22.8 ms, respectively. The largest τ for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 demonstrated that photogenerated electrons more hardly reach the back contact, which may be caused by reintroduced surface traps in M-Fe2O3. The introduction of M-TiO2 not only constructs a well-interconnected interface but also greatly reduces the transmission resistance, thus accelerating the electron transfer, confirmed by the minimum value of τ for Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2.

In addition, the chopped LSV curve of the optimal Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 in e exhibits indiscernible transient current spikes, indicating the minimum amount of hole accumulation, viz., the holes trapped by the surface shallow traps are rapidly involved in water oxidation. These positive shallow traps act as the outstanding OER active site, combined with its porous structure and water permeability characteristics, resulting in superior surface OER kinetics. As shown in the Tafel slope in Figure S17, the Tafel slope of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2 is 237 mV·dec–1, which is significantly lower than those of Fe2O3 (368 mV·dec–1) and Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3 (334 mV·dec–1), denoting the dramatically increased OER efficiency of Fe2O3/M-Fe2O3/M-TiO2.
